Birnbaum v. Pamoukis, 595 N.E.2d 836 (Ma.proposition: This Complaint is based on Massachusetts negligence law and caselaw, including but not limited to:
Birnbaum v. Pamoukis, 595 N.E.2d 836 (Ma.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not Birnbaum v. Pamoukis, 595 N.E.2d 836 (Mass. 1992); it is a New York Court of Appeals criminal case concerning a defendant’s right to be present at a Sandoval hearing. It does not involve Massachusetts negligence law or any civil tort principles. Therefore, it cannot support a proposition that a complaint is based on Massachusetts negligence law and caselaw.
Birnbaum v. Pamoukis, 595 N.E.2d 836 (Ma.relevant_excerpt: "A defendant’s presence at trial is required not only by the Confrontation and Due Process Clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions (see, US Const 6th, 14th Amends; NY Const, art I, § 6), but also by CPL 260.20, which provides that '[a] defendant must be personally present during the trial of an indictment.'"

Bulatao v. Almeda, 726 N.E.2d 1215 (Mass.proposition: This Complaint is based on Massachusetts negligence law and caselaw, including but not limited to:
Bulatao v. Almeda, 726 N.E.2d 1215 (Mass.support_reasoning: The proposition claims the complaint is based on Massachusetts negligence law and caselaw. Bulatao v. Almeda is a Massachusetts case, but the supplied opinion text is actually Menard, Inc. v. Dage‑MTI, Inc., an Indiana Supreme Court decision addressing corporate officers’ inherent authority in contract, not Massachusetts negligence principles. Because the opinion does not discuss Massachusetts negligence law at all, it does not support the cited proposition.
Bulatao v. Almeda, 726 N.E.2d 1215 (Mass.relevant_excerpt:
We hold that as president, Sterling possessed the inherent authority to bind Dage in these circumstances.

Two main classifications of authority are generally recognized: “actual authority” and “apparent authority.” ... We find the concept of inherent authority — rather than actual or apparent authority — controls our analysis in this case.

Vautour, 569 N.E.2d 319 (Mas.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that the complaint is based on Massachusetts negligence law and caselaw, but the provided opinion text is not from Sullivan v. Sullivan v. Vautour, 569 N.E.2d 319 (Mas.relevant_excerpt: "The majority opinion accurately states the law applicable to this situation, but in my opinion erroneously affirms the trial court in its misapplication of the law. When one reviews the majority’s opinion and compares the disclaimer of contract in the instant case with that in Perman v. ArcVentures, Inc. (1990), 196 Ill. App. 3d 758, 554 N.E.2d 982, cited by the majority, one finds that the disclaimer in the Perman case was much stronger, yet enforceable contractual rights concerning discharge procedures were found."
